title: Stormont to discuss abortion decriminalisation in Northern Ireland
text:
An abortion rights protester holds a ‘The North is Next’ sign during a march in Dublin, Ireland, in September (Picture: PA)

Northern Irish leaders will gather in Belfast today for the first time in two and a half years to protest against abortion rights.

The Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) and other anti-abortion members of the Northern Ireland Assembly will stage the symbolic recall at midday today.

The assembly – more commonly referred to as Stormont – is the devolved legislature of Northern Ireland.

It has power to legislate in a wide range of areas that are not explicitly reserved to Parliament in Westminster.

But it collapsed in January 2017 and has been in a period of suspension ever since amid a bitter row between the DUP and Sinn Fein.

Subsequent discussions to restore the assembly have been unsuccessful.

During its suspension, MPs in the House of Commons have passed some key legislation for Northern Ireland.

Advertisement

The region’s near-blanket ban on abortion is due to end at midnight today after a historic vote in the Commons in July to bring Northern Ireland into line with the rest of the UK.

Amnesty International at Belfast’s High court calling for a review of Northern Ireland’s abortion laws (Picture: PA)

Abortion was legalised in Ireland in 2018 and campaigners there have been protesting for the law change to be replicated in the North of the island (Picture: PA)

The bid to recall the assembly had been proposed by Northern Ireland peer Baroness O’Loan, who opposes the reform.

Under the existing abortion law, women in Northern Ireland face up to life in jail for having a termination.

The noon sitting today will be largely symbolic, as the assembly cannot perform legislative functions without a ministerial executive in place.

Last week the anti-abortion campaign group Both Lives Matter said 31 members of the legislative assembly (MLAs) – including 27 from the DUP – signed a petition forcing the recall to discuss a motion to put abortion rights back in the hands of local politicians.

It is not clear if MLAs will be able to debate the abortion law changes as they first have to elect a speaker with cross-community support.

Rival MLAs have branded the recall ‘a meaningless stunt’ but members taking part say it will provide a forum to voice opposition to the decriminalisation of abortion in the region.

While anti-abortion members are set to attend, the rest of the chamber’s benches are expected to stay empty.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Sinn Fein said its members will not turn up to the sitting it described as a ‘circus’.

Nigel Dodds and Arlene Foster, deputy and leader of the DUP, who are against decriminalising abortion in Northern Ireland (Picture: PA)

Pro-choice supporters in Parliament Square in May, ahead of the law change in Westminster in July (Picture: PA)

MPs at Westminster successfully amended the Executive Formation Act 2019 in the summer to include measures to end the near blanket ban on abortion and introduce same sex marriage.

Once the 19th Century laws that criminalise abortion end at midnight, the Government will assume responsibility for introducing new regulations to provide greater access to terminations in Northern Ireland by next April.

In the interim period, women will be offered free transport to access abortion services in England.

Under the Act, same sex marriage will become legal in Northern Ireland in January, with the first wedding expected the following month.

The law changes regarding abortion and marriage could only be stopped if the crisis-hit Stormont is revived prior to the midnight deadline. It is extremely unlikely to happen.

description: Northern Ireland's near-blanket ban on abortion is due to end at midnight after MPs voted to bring the region into line with the rest of the UK.
